diagnoses.name: Sepsis
diagnoses.description: A life-threatening condition caused by the body's response to an infection.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the immune system attacks its own tissues, causing widespread inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Acute Pyelonephritis
diagnoses.description: A type of kidney infection.
common_symptoms: pain in the back or side

diagnoses.name: Urinary Tract Infection (UTI)
diagnoses.description: An infection in any part of the urinary system.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the fluid and membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain, often caused by a viral infection.

diagnoses.name: Endocarditis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the inner lining of your heart chambers and valves.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Storm
diagnoses.description: A life-threatening health condition that is associated with untreated or under-treated hyperthyroidism.

diagnoses.name: Acute Kidney Injury
diagnoses.description: A sudden episode of kidney failure or kidney damage that happens within a few hours or a few days.

diagnoses.name: Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening reaction to neuroleptic or antipsychotic medication.

diagnoses: Viral Infections (e.g., Dengue Fever, Zika Virus)
Schizophrenia (in the context of psychosis with other non-specific symptoms)
Viral Infections (e.g., Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with nephritis, arthropathy (joint pain), pleural effusion, and a characteristic discoid rash. Neuropsychiatric symptoms, potentially resembling delirium, can also occur.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune disorder that may feature a combination of symptoms seen in lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including joint pain (arthropathy), renal involvement (nephritis), lung issues like pleural effusion, and skin rashes.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid arthritis with lung involvement
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily affects joints (arthropathy) but can also cause lung problems (including pleural effusion) and skin manifestations; renal involvement is less common but can occur in advanced stages or due to medication side effects.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced lupus erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: Certain medications can induce a lupus-like syndrome, presenting with features like nephritis, arthropathy, pleural effusion, and skin rash. Symptoms usually improve upon discontinuation of the offending drug.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily affecting exocrine glands leading to dry eyes and mouth, it can also present with joint pain (arthropathy), lung involvement (pleural effusion), and renal issues. Skin manifestations are less common but possible.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: A group of disorders that involve inflammation of the blood vessels. Depending on the specific type, it can cause skin rashes (including discoid rashes), kidney disease (nephritis), joint pain (arthropathy), and lung involvement (pleural effusion).

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: An inflammatory condition characterized by muscle weakness and skin rashes. It can occasionally lead to lung issues like pleural effusion and, less commonly, joint pain and kidney involvement.

diagnoses.name: Infective endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: An infection of the heart valves that can cause a wide array of symptoms, including skin manifestations (like Osler's nodes that can sometimes resemble discoid rashes), joint pain (arthropathy), kidney involvement (nephritis), and pleural effusion due to infection spread or emboli.

diagnoses.name: Lyme disease
diagnoses.rationale: Caused by Borrelia burgdorferi and transmitted by ticks, it can lead to joint pain (arthropathy), heart, nervous system (potentially including symptoms of delirium), and kidney involvement. Skin rash (erythema migrans) is common but may not always appear discoid.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: A disease involving abnormal collections of inflammatory cells (granulomas) that can form as nodules in multiple organs, leading to symptoms such as arthropathy, lung involvement (including pleural effusion), skin rashes, and potentially kidney involvement.

diagnoses: Viral or bacterial infection triggering autoimmune response
Vitamin deficiency (e.g., Vitamin B12, Vitamin A)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.description: Anxiety Disorder
diagnoses.reason: Anxiety can present with cognitive dysfunction, attention deficits, and somatic symptoms such as presyncope (feeling faint). Stress can exacerbate or trigger dyshydrotic eczema.

diagnoses.description: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reason: Can cause cognitive dysfunction, attention deficits, and skin manifestations. Dysregulation of the thyroid can sometimes lead to the formation of cysts.

diagnoses.description: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.reason: PCOS can result in the development of cysts and is associated with mood swings and cognitive issues due to hormonal imbalances. Skin conditions such as eczema can also be exacerbated by hormonal changes.

diagnoses.description: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.reason: Characterized by cognitive dysfunction and attention deficits, often referred to as 'fibro fog'. Fibromyalgia doesn't directly cause cysts or eczema but can be associated with a wide range of symptoms including skin sensitivities.

diagnoses.description: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS)
diagnoses.reason: Presents with cognitive dysfunction and attention deficits. While not directly causing cysts or eczema, individuals with CFS may experience a variety of nonspecific symptoms, including skin disorders.

diagnoses.description: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reason: Can lead to cognitive dysfunction due to variations in blood glucose levels. Skin conditions such as eczema can be more common in people with diabetes, and cysts may form in relation to skin infections or other complications.

diagnoses.description: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.reason: Can cause cognitive dysfunction and attention deficits. Though not directly linked to dyshydrotic eczema or cysts, B12 deficiency affects skin health and might exacerbate or contribute to their occurrence.

diagnoses.description: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.reason: MS can cause cognitive dysfunction and attention deficits. While MS doesn't primarily lead to dyshydrotic eczema or cysts, its wide range of neurological symptoms can overlap with the ones mentioned.

diagnoses.description: Neuroendocrine Tumors
diagnoses.reason: These tumors can cause a variety of symptoms including cognitive dysfunction and skin changes. Though not typically associated with dyshydrotic eczema, the connection to cyst formation exists.

diagnoses.description: Lupus
diagnoses.reason: Systemic lupus erythematosus can cause a wide array of symptoms, including cognitive issues and skin manifestations. Lupus patients may also have non-specific symptoms such as presyncope and attention deficits.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. In people with sarcoidosis, abnormal masses or nodules consisting of inflamed tissues form in certain organs of the body.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's characterized by periods of illness, called flares, and periods of wellness, or remission.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the glands that make moisture. It most often causes dryness in the mouth and eyes.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in infection-fighting cells of the immune system, called lymphocytes. These cells are in the lymph nodes, spleen, thymus, bone marrow, and other parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Amyloidosis
diagnoses.description: A rare disease that occurs when a substance called amyloid builds up in your organs. Amyloid is an abnormal protein that is produced in your bone marrow and can be deposited in any tissue or organ.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complicated disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. The fatigue worsens with physical or mental activity, but doesn't improve with rest.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that causes overlapping features of three diseases: lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis. MCTD may also have features of rheumatoid arthritis.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) is a virus that attacks the body's immune system. If HIV is not treated, it can lead to Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS).

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing inflammation in blood vessels throughout your body. The inflammation leads to numerous symptoms that can include mouth sores, genital sores, inflammation of parts of the eye, and skin abnormalities.

diagnoses: Autoimmune Diseases (e.g., Systemic Lupus Erythematosus, Sjögren's syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
diagnoses.reason: Hyperactivity is a core symptom.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.reason: Connects to angioedema; a genetic disorder causing swelling beneath the skin.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes
diagnoses.reason: Poor healing can be a complication due to impaired blood flow and nerve damage.

diagnoses.name: Blepharospasm
diagnoses.reason: Direct correlation to symptom; a condition causing involuntary tight closure of the eyelids.

diagnoses.name: Sensorineural Hearing Loss
diagnoses.reason: Direct relation to hearing loss, potentially due to nerve damage.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.reason: Can cause hyperactivity due to elevated thyroid hormone levels.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: Poor healing and other symptoms can be due to cortisol overproduction.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reason: Can cause a wide range of symptoms including poor healing and swelling (angioedema-like).

diagnoses.name: Allergic Reactions
diagnoses.reason: Angioedema is often a symptom of severe allergic reactions.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Inner Ear Disease (AIED)
diagnoses.reason: Can cause progressive hearing loss due to an autoimmune response affecting the inner ear.

diagnoses: Acute Kidney Injury (superimposed on chronic kidney disease)
Medication side effect or adverse reaction

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.details: Complex neurological condition characterized by recurrent headaches accompanied by sensory and motor symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.details: A medical condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms like aphasia and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.details: A demyelinating disease in which the insulating covers of nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord are damaged.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.details: Abnormal growth of cells within the brain or inside the skull, which can lead to various neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.details: Inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.details: Inflammation of the brain, caused by infection or an autoimmune response.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.details: A collection of pus that develops in the brain due to an infection.

diagnoses.name: Cerebral Aneurysm
diagnoses.details: A weak bulging spot on the wall of a brain artery that can cause various neurological impairments if ruptured.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.details: Often called a mini-stroke, a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.details: A condition resulting from restricted blood flow to the back of the brain, causing symptoms like dizziness, ataxia, and weakness.

diagnoses: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, formerly Wegener's granulomatosis)
Lupus Nephritis (for proteinuria in the context of lupus)
Vasculitis (generic, considering nasal ulcers and proteinuria)
Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
Discoid Lupus Erythematosus (DLE, for nonscarring alopecia, less likely given the combination of symptoms)
Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA, formerly Wegener's Granulomatosis)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease characterized by inflammation of various parts of the body. It can manifest with skin, joint, kidney, heart, and nervous system involvement, explaining the wide range of symptoms including nonscarring alopecia, hemolytic anemia, arthropathy, and pericardial effusion. Delirium can occur in severe cases or when the central nervous system is affected.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. While primarily known for causing arthropathy, it can also cause systemic manifestations such as anemia (though typically anemia of chronic disease rather than hemolytic anemia) and, less commonly, pericardial effusion. Neurological manifestations like delirium are rare but possible, especially in the context of severe disease or complications.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the combination of autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) and immune thrombocytopenia (ITP). It might show symptoms like hemolytic anemia, and, though less common, it can be associated with other autoimmune manifestations that could potentially explain some of the other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A group of autoimmune diseases where the immune system becomes hyperactive and attacks normal, healthy tissues. Symptoms include those fitting systemic lupus erythematosus such as nonscarring alopecia, hemolytic anemia, arthropathy, and pericardial effusion. Delirium could be associated with severe disease stages or CNS involvement.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that displays features of three other connective tissue diseases—systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, and polymyositis—along with high levels of a substance known as ribonucleoprotein (RNP) antibodies. Patients can present with arthropathy, pericardial effusion, nonscarring alopecia, and hemolytic anemia. Neurological symptoms like delirium can also be present but are less common.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune condition characterized by the destruction of the salivary and lacrimal glands, leading to dryness of the mouth and eyes. While primarily known for sicca symptoms, it can present with systemic features like arthropathy and hematologic abnormalities including anemia. Neurological manifestations are possible, including cognitive dysfunction or, rarely, delirium.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.description: A group of autoimmune diseases that cause the skin and connective tissues to harden and tighten. Systemic forms of the disease can also involve the joints, blood vessels, and internal organs, potentially leading to symptoms like arthropathy and pericardial effusion. Hemolytic anemia and delirium are less commonly associated.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by the body's immune system mistakenly attacking certain proteins in the blood, leading to blood clots. While primarily known for thrombotic events, it can also be associated with hemolytic anemia and, in severe cases, might contribute to organ complications that present with symptoms like arthropathy or pericardial effusion. Neurological manifestations can include a wide range of symptoms, potentially including delirium.

diagnoses.name: Hemophagocytic Lymphohistiocytosis (HLH)
diagnoses.description: A rare but potentially life-threatening condition often resulting from an uncontrolled and ineffective immune response. It involves fever, splenomegaly, cytopenias, including hemolytic anemia, and can include neurological symptoms like delirium. Arthropathy and pericardial effusion can be features of the systemic inflammation present in HLH.

diagnoses.name: Still's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare type of inflammatory arthritis characterized by fevers, rash, and joint pain. Adult Still's disease can include a wide array of systemic symptoms, including arthropathy and pericardial effusion. Anemia can be present, although hemolytic anemia specifically would be less common. Neurologic manifestations like delirium are possible but rare.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Infectious Diseases (e.g., Viral or Bacterial Infections that could lead to secondary hemolytic anemia, pericarditis or other symptoms)
